text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to how to Thai Kitchen I'm 
making one time soup today and now I know some

of you might be thinking isn't that Chinese 
food and you're right however there's a lot

of Chinese influence on Thai cuisine and this is 
one of them we eat wontons a lot we fry them we

boil them we do a lot of things with them but 
today we're gonna do the simple basic wontons

which is such comfort food I love it let's get 
started I'm gonna start out by making an herb

paste to flavor the filling and I'm using 
a very familiar set of ingredients and that

is garlic white peppercorns and cilantro stems 
now normally I use cilantro roots but I didn't

have any on hand so cilantro stems chopped up 
just like that works fine this paste is such

a great basic flavor base for a lot of things in 
my spring rolls I use this as a base marinades I

use this as a base I mean this is sort of our 
version of the French mirepoix all right I'm

gonna switch tools and move on to something 
electric making this filling is the easiest

thing in the world you just dump everything in 
and blitzen you're done I'm using two types of

protein today starting with ground pork and I 
am not using lean ground pork you can if you

want but I like that a little bit of tenderness 
from the fat the other protein I'm using a shrimp

now you don't have to add shrimp you can just 
do all pork and you don't have to do pork you

can do ground chicken or ground turkey if you want 
something leaner but I do find that a combination

of shrimp and pork is better than shrimp alone so 
an egg to help bind everything together and also

to tenderize the mixture a little bit seasoning 
now some soy sauce going in oyster sauce when I

add oyster sauce it just get this feeling that 
like that's gonna be good it just looks so good

and my herb paste that I made just now a little 
bit of sweetness to balance the salt just some

sugar you won't taste a sweetness but it will 
create a well-balanced flavor and finally tapioca

starch helps the texture of the filling become a 
little more tender that is it close it off I go

don't overdo this you don't want a complete 
peace you're just trying to get the shrimp

to be no longer chunky little pieces of shrimp 
is fine you're really going for something like

that so you still have some character in it 
if this is your first time making it you want

to taste it first because there's no fixing 
it once we stuff it in the wonton so take a

little you know a little teaspoon of this mixture 
microwave it for 10 to 15 seconds just to cook it

through and see if you need to add more sugar or 
more soy sauce more oyster sauce to get it right

before it's irreversible as some of you know I 
don't like to roll spring rolls or skewer meats

wrapping wontons is another one of those tasks 
but it isn't necessary evil and the result is so

worth it that I am gonna do it anyway one tip 
I will give you is go with the brands that is

thinnest just look at the package and look at 
the side and you can sort of tell which brand

is thicker than another and when you're not 
working with these just put them under a towel

or something so they don't dry out okay around a 
teaspoon is enough any more than that and you'll

have a hard time closing them and there that's it 
that's enough it doesn't look like a lot but trust

me it will also swell up puff up a little bit 
when they're cooked you can wrap this a million

ways but I'm gonna show you the easiest least 
painful way that I like and I'll make another

video a supplementary video that shows you the 
other cool ways you can do this but here is my

favorite you pull it up and you give it a little 
squeeze and it's done you don't need any water any

glue and because the pork is sticky it will hold 
on the park itself acts like glue and then you get

this sort of like fluffy ruffled edge that I think 
is kind of cute so you just gather all the edges

give it a little squeeze so it's sort 
of secured in there and there you go

now I'm gonna make the broth for the wontons 
to swim in now you want to start with a good

pork stock if you don't eat pork you can also do 
chicken stock but pork stock is traditional and

if you don't know how to make a good stock I have 
a video for that by the way while you're making

this soup you want to have another pot of water 
for boiling your wontons going so we're efficient

very simple seasoning I've got some soy sauce 
a little bit of salt I don't want to do all soy

sauce because I don't want it to be dark I still 
want a light-colored soup and a splash of fish

sauce just a little splash I just feel like the 
sharpness of the fish sauce really gives the broth

a little ah and then to cut all that saltiness 
just a little bit of sugar again you're not

going to taste sweet but you're just gonna taste a 
well-balanced saltiness and then a splash of white

pepper you can go as much or as little as you want 
white pepper is quite potent so if you don't like

a lot of sort of hot pepperiness to go light on 
it okay and that's it that is the rock so because

it is simple that is so important that you have a 
good stock otherwise it's just not gonna be good

with the wonton soup I like to have a little bit 
of greens and you can do any kind of greens you

want but some bok choy baby bok choy is great so 
I just take one head and just split it in half if

you want some vegetables some blanch vegetable if 
you want to cook them before you cook the wontons

because once you put the wontons in here the 
water will be all murky with all the flour just

one minute once your once once these are done I'm 
gonna put them directly into the serving bowl try

not to get too much of the cooking waters you 
don't want to dilute your broth if you want to

blend space in advance shock them into cold water 
and then reheat them again in boiling water when

you're ready to serve all right wonton time these 
are only going to take about 1 1 and 1/2 minutes

because they're so small you can make these in 
advance leave them in the fridge and cook them

the next day you can even freeze them and then 
cook them but if you freeze them they will take

a little bit longer to cook so I like to let them 
thaw first and just nudge them off the bottom they

do like to stick and that's it I'm gonna take 
these now make sure you shake off as much water

as you can place that down oh it's okay no I'm 
good with just five but some people might want

to do 6 8 10 per serving so completely up to you 
just some broth over the wontons mmm now to make

this tie I'm gonna add some fried garlic now this 
is just some chopped garlic that I fried in oil

we use this to top most of our sort of noodle soup 
type things and I do have a tutorial on that on my

garlic pepper chicken video and this trust me is 
gonna add a lot of good good garlicky flavor and

to make this even more time gonna add a little 
spiciness I've got here just some chili oil now

yes you can buy chili oil already made but all 
I did here was I just fried up some Thai dried

chilies red chilies in some oil and that's it you 
got chili oil just over low heat so you don't burn

the chilies it's a nice color nice spice I'm 
just going to chop up some fresh green onions

to top it off and that is it that's wonton soup 
now without further ado I am going to taste this

subtle and well-balanced that's really how 
I can describe this unlike many other dishes

that I dude it doesn't have that punch in the 
face strong flavors of all types of herbs and

whatnot it's just simple comforting goodness 
but that Cape of chili oil a little bit spicy

in the throat brings everything together 
this is super easy to make a wontons in

advance bring them out and boil them whenever 
you can the stock can be frozen so there's a

lot of ways you can turn this into a simple 
weeknight dinner material so I hope you give

this a try the recipes on Hawkeye catching
